items.title: The White House Spanish-language site is shut down by the Trump administration
items.summary:
- Within hours of [President Donald Trump’s inauguration](https://www.fastcompany.com/91262225/trump-inauguration-list-of-performances-attendees-tiktok-ceo-shou-chew-village-people), the Spanish-language version of the official White House website was taken down.
- The site now returns a “Error 404” message and included a button linking to a video montage of Trump’s first term.
- Hispanic advocacy groups expressed confusion and frustration over the abrupt shutdown, highlighting the administration's lack of communication with the Latino community.
- White House officials stated they are committed to restoring the Spanish translation section of the website.
- Trump's removal of the Spanish site in 2017 was followed by a reinstatement by President Joe Biden in 2021. 
- The removal coincided with Trump's immigration crackdown and a national emergency declaration at the U.S.-Mexico border.
- Approximately 43.4 million Americans speak Spanish at home, representing 13.7% of the U.S. population over age 5.
- Experts noted that the shutdown limits access to information for millions of Spanish-speaking Americans and casts doubt on which constituencies the administration prioritizes.

items.title: ‘What are your values?’ Barby Siegel explains corporate communications in the Trump era
items.author: Barby Siegel
items.summary:
- Businesses are preparing for changes as Donald Trump takes office for a second term.
- Barby Siegel emphasizes the importance of aligning corporate values with societal issues while navigating communication challenges.
- Calls for companies to assess their authentic values before engaging in political discourse.
- Importance of diversity, equity, and inclusion in current corporate strategies post-Inauguration Day.
- Communication strategies now require a balance between external pressures and internal values, with employees playing a crucial role.

items.title: Facebook’s group moderators are its last, best hope
items.author: Harry McCracken
items.summary:
- Facebook's group moderators play a crucial role in maintaining community standards in millions of groups.
- Moderators have the autonomy to manage their groups using tools provided by Facebook, enhancing community engagement.
- The article discusses a recent decision by a group moderator to ban AI-generated artwork to preserve human creativity within the community.
- Users are expressing discontent with recent changes at Meta, highlighting the importance of dedicated moderators for community sustainability.

items.title: Is Elon Musk a government employee? Here’s why it matters
items.author: Chris Morris
items.summary:
- Elon Musk's role with the Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE) remains unclear, despite his close relationship with Donald Trump.
- The designation as a ‘special government employee’ would have significant legal and business implications for Musk, particularly regarding conflict-of-interest laws.
- DOGE will reorganize an existing division (the United States Digital Service) and report directly to the White House chief of staff.

items.title: Trump to announce $500 billion private sector AI infrastructure investment
items.author: Not given
items.summary:
- President [Donald Trump](https://www.fastcompany.com/section/donald-trump) is set to announce a private sector investment of up to $500 billion in [artificial intelligence infrastructure](https://www.fastcompany.com/section/artificial-intelligence) on Tuesday.
- A joint venture named Stargate, involving [OpenAI](https://www.fastcompany.com/section/openai), [SoftBank](https://www.fastcompany.com/91248322/japanese-tech-giant-softbank-investing-over-100-billion-u-s-heres-why), and [Oracle](https://www.fastcompany.com/section/oracle), has initially committed $100 billion with a potential total of $500 billion over the next four years.
- Key figures including SoftBank CEO Masayoshi Son, OpenAI's Sam Altman, and Oracle's Larry Ellison are expected to attend the White House announcement; Oracle shares rose by 6% amid the news.

items.title: Why Trump dashed Biden’s AI executive order, and why it matters
items.summary:
- President Trump revoked Biden’s 2023 AI executive order shortly after taking power.
- Biden’s EO aimed to regulate AI to address societal and national security risks.
- Trump campaigned on repealing the EO, citing concerns from the tech industry about onerous requirements.
- The Biden EO required AI developers to submit safety testing data to the government.
- During Biden's term, many government agencies advanced their own AI initiatives.
- Trump’s own 2020 AI executive order focused on increasing research funding and establishing research institutes.

items.title: These tech leaders have jobs in the Trump administration
items.summary:
- President Trump has appointed several tech executives in his second administration.
- Elon Musk is set to run the Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE).
- David Sacks is appointed as White House AI and crypto czar.
- Emil Michael is nominated as undersecretary of defense for research and engineering.
- Scott Kupor is chosen for director of the office of personnel management.
- Sriram Krishnan is named senior policy advisor for artificial intelligence.

items.title: ‘We’ve got 1,460 days to go’: This TikTok creator is monitoring egg prices under Trump
items.summary:
- A TikTok creator named @magdacious is tracking egg prices throughout Trump's presidency, starting from his first day back in office.
- On day one, organic eggs were reported at various prices: $6.99 for Pete and Gerry’s, $5.99 for Bowl & Basket, and $7.79 for Vital Farms at Whole Foods.
- The TikTok series has gained 1.3 million views in less than 24 hours, attracting attention due to its relevance in Trump's campaign pledges to lower grocery prices.

items.title: ‘It’s not enjoyable to make music now’: AI music platform CEO is under fire for going after human creativity
items.author: Mikey Shulman
items.summary:
- Mikey Shulman, CEO of AI music platform Suno, stated on a podcast that making music is currently unenjoyable for many.
- He argues that traditional music creation requires extensive time and practice, which discourages people.
- Shulman believes generative AI platforms like Suno can simplify music production, allowing users to create full songs from simple prompts.
- His comments sparked backlash, with critics accusing him of undermining the value of commitment and talent in music.
- Shulman later clarified that he did not intend to belittle the creative process but wanted to highlight accessibility issues in music-making.

items.title: ‘Pouring oil in my belly button every night’: The navel pulling trend is taking over TikTok
items.summary:
- The trend involves applying castor oil to the belly button for perceived health benefits.
- TikTok videos show users claiming it aids digestion and helps reduce bloating.
- Historical context links the practice to ancient Ayurvedic healing techniques.
- Experts note a lack of scientific evidence supporting this practice's effectiveness on internal organs.
- Castor oil is recognized for its laxative properties, but its topical application remains under-researched.

items.title: This app locks you out of social media until you go for a walk
items.author: Paul English, Michael English, Rachel Cohen
items.summary:
- A new iOS app called Steppin blocks social media access until users meet their daily step count.
- Users can decide how many steps correspond to time on social media apps and can unlock it after meeting their goal.
- The app aims to reduce screen time and improve mental and physical health, targeting Gen Z but appealing to users of all ages.
- The idea was developed by Paul English and his family during a vacation in Spain due to excessive phone usage.
- Steppin is currently free but may switch to a subscription model around $20 per month in the future.

items.title: Is Meta’s Movie Gen the Future of Video Storytelling or a Threat to Creativity?
items.author: Victor Dey
items.summary:
- Meta unveiled Movie Gen, a generative AI model for creating realistic video clips from user prompts, in October.
- Users can generate videos up to 16 seconds long and audio clips up to 45 seconds long.
- Mark Zuckerberg showcased its capabilities with a leg-pressing video, announcing it will come to Instagram next year.
- Meta plans to replace mid-level software engineers with AI by 2025 and shift to a community notes model for fact-checking.
- The company previously faced backlash for AI-generated character accounts, leading to their removal from platforms.
- Movie Gen features a 30B parameter text-to-video model, generating lifelike videos with synchronized audio.
- Competitors include OpenAI's Sora and Google's Veo, which offer longer video capabilities and enhanced creative control.
- Meta claims Movie Gen outperforms competitors like Sora and Kling in video quality and realism.

items.title: TikTok ban on hold for 75 days, but Trump may make a deal with China
items.summary:
- President Trump signed an executive order delaying the TikTok ban by 75 days, initially scheduled for January 19.
- Trump suggested a potential half ownership of TikTok's U.S. business to keep the app operational and warned of tariffs if China does not approve a U.S. deal.
- The TikTok ban issue arose as the app serves 170 million Americans, and legal maneuvers left users anxious about its future.
- Following Trump's intervention, TikTok restored its service in the U.S., yet it remains unavailable for download in app stores.

items.title: How Trump shifted from banning TikTok to saving it
items.summary:
- Donald Trump initially sought to ban TikTok, claiming it was a national security threat.
- As president-elect, Trump announced plans to delay the ban to negotiate a deal for national security.
- TikTok resumed operations in the U.S., announcing it was back thanks to Trump’s efforts.
- Trump’s authority to halt the ban is legally unclear, but it reflects shifts in tech and national security debates.
- TikTok has 170 million users, especially popular among younger Americans.

items.title: Elon Musk keeps hyping up his self-driving robotaxis. Can he ever deliver?
items.summary:
• In 2019, Musk promised one million self-driving robotaxis by 2022, which did not materialize.
• The release date was pushed to 2023 and then to a flexible target of 2027 for the Cybercab design.
• Tesla's FSD technology has improved but still requires human supervision and is not fully autonomous.
• Musk claims significant growth in FSD capabilities, increasing highway miles before disengagement from 85 to 724 miles.
• Musk predicts Tesla's FSD will surpass human driver safety by Q2 2025, as Tesla employees conduct autonomous trials.

items.title: Is it OK to ask your friends to unfollow your ex?
Build your focus stack with these proven tools and gadgets
items.summary:
- The article discusses the challenge of maintaining focus in a distracted environment.
- It presents a three-layer system for productivity: planning tools, focus tools, and analysis tools.
- Each layer is designed to enhance concentration and improve long-term work habits.

items.title: TikTok ban in effect. The app goes dark for millions in the U.S. and removed from app stores
items.summary:
- Millions of TikTok users in the U.S. unable to access the app due to a federal ban.
- TikTok removed from app stores, including those operated by Apple and Google, on Saturday evening.
- Users were met with a message stating "Sorry, TikTok isn’t available right now," indicating the app's unavailability.
- Acknowledgement of President-elect Trump's intention to work on a solution to reinstate TikTok.
- Users can download their data via the website, but the duration of the unavailability remains uncertain.

items.title: Tired of Notion? Sick of Slack? This site will help you find free alternatives
items.summary:
- Many apps and services are moving to subscription models, leading to cost concerns.
- A new community-run website offers free or cheaper alternatives to popular apps.
- The tool to find alternatives is called [AlternativeTo](https://alternativeto.net/) and aggregates crowdsourced information on app alternatives.

items.title: Mark Zuckerberg says Apple hasn’t innovated since the iPhone. He’s forgetting about this one major thing
items.summary:
- Mark Zuckerberg criticizes Apple for lacking innovation since the iPhone, stating it has been 'sitting on it' for years.
- His comments reflect frustration with Apple’s App Store fees, which Apple recently reduced for small developers.
- Zuckerberg's view underscores a misunderstanding, as Apple's recent innovations, particularly in privacy, have impacted Meta's business model.
- Apple’s data privacy features, especially in iOS 18, limit access for apps like Meta, which depend on extensive user data.

items.title: The TikTok era comes to an end: Creators are revealing their secrets, saying goodbye ahead of the U.S. ban
items.summary:
- TikTok influencers are sharing secrets and saying goodbye as the platform faces a likely ban in the U.S. by January 19.
- The Supreme Court upheld a law requiring TikTok to divest from its Chinese parent company.
- Creators are urging followers to connect on other platforms before TikTok potentially shuts down.
- Users are migrating to Xiaohongshu (RedNote) due to its similarities with TikTok.
- Content includes playful confessions about staged viral trends and videos highlighting creators' popular posts.

items.title: The Supreme Court’s decision on TikTok may have just turned a generation off politics
items.summary:
- The Supreme Court upheld a law requiring TikTok’s parent company, ByteDance, to sell the app or face a ban in two days.
- TikTok has around 170 million users, predominantly younger, politically engaged individuals.
- The decision marks a significant shift, potentially disillusioning younger voters who oppose the ban.

items.title: Supreme Court upholds TikTok ban. No one knows what comes next
items.summary:
- The Supreme Court upheld a law requiring TikTok to shut down unless its parent company sells the app by Sunday.
- The ruling addresses national security risks associated with TikTok's data practices and relationship with China.
- Critics fear the decision sets a precedent for government suppression of free speech, with significant implications for TikTok's 170 million U.S. users.
- The ruling stems from the Protecting Americans from Foreign Adversary Controlled Applications Act, signed into law by President Biden.

items.title: Elon Musk’s Starship rocket explodes during SpaceX flight test
items.summary:
- SpaceX's Starship rocket broke up in space shortly after launch from Texas.
- The incident occurred at 5:38 p.m. EST, leading to altered airline flights to avoid debris.
- SpaceX lost contact with the rocket eight minutes post-liftoff, confirming the loss.
- Past failures had less impact on air traffic, but this incident caused significant disruptions.

items.title: TikTok ban will not be enforced by Biden
items.author: Zeke Miller, Josh Boak, Michelle L. Price, Mary Clare Jalonick
items.summary:
- President Biden will not enforce the TikTok ban set before his term ends.
- The decision leaves TikTok's future to President-elect Trump.
- TikTok's parent company, ByteDance, must divest by January 19.
- Trump's team may find ways to keep TikTok operational in the U.S.
- Senate Democratic Leader Chuck Schumer advocates for extending the divestment deadline.
- Legal challenges to the ban are ongoing in the Supreme Court.
- Trump has shifted his stance on TikTok, now supporting its availability in the U.S.

items.title: ‘There’s no stone left unturned’: Alejandro Mayorkas on bringing AI into the DHS
items.summary:
- Alejandro Mayorkas faced significant challenges as Secretary of DHS, including impeachment and managing crises like fentanyl and natural disasters.
- He emphasizes the department's swift response to the generative AI boom, leading in its adoption and governance.
- Key achievements include the establishment of an AI roadmap, policies for AI use, and the hiring of 49 AI technologists to form the AI Corps.
- Mayorkas highlights the creation of a machine to simulate refugee applicants for training purposes, reflecting his personal experiences as a refugee.

items.title: Makers of autonomous vehicles want to change the world—but first they want to change regulations
items.summary:
- Aurora Innovation filed a court case after regulators denied an exemption from the safety triangle requirement for its autonomous trucks.
- The company proposes using flashing lights instead, claiming this small change could significantly impact road safety laws.
- The move is supported by organizations like the Fraternal Order of Police and the American Trucking Associations.
- Experts warn that as self-driving vehicles emerge, their creators will push for changes to existing road rules, impacting human drivers' safety and rights.

items.title: 3 big predictions for AI in financial services in 2025
items.summary:
- AI will enhance efficiency in financial services through collaborative approaches, streamlining processes in the background.
- Providers will focus on creating personalized solutions using existing customer data, making services feel seamless.
- The trend will shift towards specialization with bundled niche solutions tailored to specific customer segments, rather than trying to serve everyone.

items.title: With full speed ahead on AI investment, does ROI matter?
items.author: Sowmyanarayan Sampath
items.summary:
- Companies should consider the return on investment (ROI) regarding AI spending to avoid unnecessary losses.
- A projected $1 trillion in spending on AI in the coming years could create significant economic value, but careful investment is crucial.
- Companies can be categorized into three types concerning AI investments: Big Tech's aggressive explorations, supply chain over-investment, and applied AI company's targeted ROI strategies.

items.title: Americans keep falsely claiming this random man from Vancouver is RedNote’s CEO
items.summary:
- Users of the Chinese app RedNote mistakenly identify Jerry from Vancouver as the platform's CEO.
- Jerry welcomed new English-speaking users with a video posted on January 13, which went viral.
- The rumor of Jerry being the CEO spread rapidly on TikTok, leading him to clarify his actual identity in a follow-up video.

items.title: TikTok refugees or propagandists? China’s RedNote users share mixed responses to U.S. influx
items.summary:
- Users of the Chinese social media app [RedNote](https://www.fastcompany.com/91260771/5-things-to-know-about-tiktok-replacement-rednote) welcomed ‘TikTok refugees’ from the U.S. with selfies and messages.
- The app has become a channel for U.S.-China exchanges, with users discussing pets, food, and life experiences.
- Over 700,000 new users have joined due to a looming U.S. ban on TikTok, which has 170 million American users.
- Some Chinese users expressed concerns about nationalist influences on the platform despite welcoming new users.

items.title: Duolingo Sees 216% Increase in U.S. Users Learning Mandarin Amid TikTok Ban
items.summary:
- Duolingo reported a 216% increase in new U.S. users learning Mandarin due to users migrating to the Chinese app RedNote amidst TikTok's impending U.S. ban set for January 19.
- More than 700 million users are leaving TikTok for RedNote, which defaults to Mandarin.
- The app's popularity also led to a 36% increase in downloads across U.S. platforms as users sought to learn the language needed for RedNote. 
- Duolingo's rank has significantly improved, now at No. 22 for Top Overall Apps and No. 20 for Top Apps.

items.title: How to test out the new Nintendo Switch 2
items.author: Mark Wilson
items.summary:
- Nintendo announced the upcoming Nintendo Switch 2, set for release later this year.
- A promotional event will allow fans to test the console in New York (April 4-6), Los Angeles (April 11-13), and Dallas (April 25-27).
- A lottery system will be used for ticket distribution, open to U.S. residents from January 17 to January 26.

items.title: One reason the U.S. government is so spooked by TikTok: AI
items.author: Mark Sullivan
items.summary:
- TikTok could face a ban in the U.S. by January 19 if the Supreme Court does not intervene regarding a law mandating a new owner.
- Concerns arise over TikTok's parent company, ByteDance, potentially sharing U.S. user data with the Chinese government, which could be weaponized by AI in the future.
- The platform's algorithm is already adept at targeting content to users, raising fears of manipulation through personalized content generation.

items.title: Why school cellphone bans are gaining steam in these red and blue states
items.author: Andrew DeMillo, Associated Press
items.summary:
- Bipartisan support for cellphone bans in schools from governors in Arkansas and California.
- Eight states have enacted cellphone bans in schools over the past two years, with ongoing discussions in others.
- Concerns over children’s mental health and classroom distractions drive the push for these bans.
- Florida's 2023 law bans cellphone use during class and prevents access to social media on school Wi-Fi.
- California requires schools to develop cellphone policies by July 2026.
- Opposition arises from parents who cite emergencies and the need for direct communication with their children.

items.title: President Biden’s new executive order aims to bolster national security
items.summary:
- President Biden issued an executive order aimed at strengthening the nation’s cybersecurity on Thursday.
- The order includes the development of minimum cybersecurity standards for government technology contractors.
- It facilitates sanctions against foreign governments responsible for cyberattacks targeting the U.S., particularly from China, Iran, Russia, and North Korea.
- Federal agencies are required to enhance cybersecurity against the threats posed by quantum computers.
- The order showcases a commitment to protect U.S. businesses and citizens from cyber threats.
- A consumer labeling program for smart devices to indicate compliance with cybersecurity standards was previously announced.

items.title: Google inks a Gemini AI chatbot deal with the Associated Press
items.summary:
- Google announces a deal with the Associated Press to deliver up-to-date news through its Gemini AI chatbot.
- AP will provide a real-time information feed to enhance the Gemini app.
- The financial details of the deal have not been disclosed, and it's unclear how Google will credit AP's journalism.
- AP's chief revenue officer stated the deal reflects their longstanding relationship with Google.
- In addition to Google, AP signed a deal with OpenAI to license its news archive for AI training.
- News organizations express concerns over AI companies using their material without permission, while tech firms argue for fair use under copyright laws.
- The AP has lost significant revenue from traditional newspaper customers but is seeking new sources of funding.
- Experts caution that reliance on tech companies may undermine news outlets' control over their work and its monetization.

items.title: How Letterboxd went mainstream
items.summary:
- In 2020, Letterboxd's highest-rated film was *Minari*, grossing $15.5 million; by 2024, *Dune: Part Two* grossed $714.4 million.
- Letterboxd's membership grew from 1.8 million in mid-2020 to over 17 million, with six million new members in the last year.
- The platform has transitioned from a niche community to a mainstream space, expanding its features and user engagement through unique lists and social media campaigns.

items.title: Substack is trying to court displaced TikTok creators
items.summary:
- Substack CEO Chris Best announces initiative to attract TikTok creators amid potential TikTok ban in the U.S.
- Offers a $25,000 prize for a TikTok video that inspires others to create content inviting audiences to join Substack.
- The winner will be revealed on January 19, regardless of TikTok's status and will get a chance to work as a creative adviser at Substack.
- Substack expands features for migrating TikTokers, providing access to long-form video, written posts, and new community engagement tools.
